our Aquarius then launched in June 1983
in the US and appeared here in the UK
the following month in July the
reception was frosty as you've probably
already guessed criticism was aimed at
its build quality in both your computer
and personal computing today magazines
and Microsoft basic was also criticized
this wasn't an extended version of
Microsoft basic but the bare minimal
implementation and that didn't even
include a command to clear the screen
instead he'd have to use this command
[Music]
there were also no commands to control
color on the screen so the user would
either need to peek and poke the
system's memory to get the desired
effect or disregard basic and work with
machine code and that was a far cry from
the truly simple slogan on the box the
competition among the low-cost micros
here in the UK however was fierce so its
price was quickly adjusted from a
hundred and sixty dollars in the u.s. to
under sixty pounds for the machine in
the UK it was then a further 30 pounds
for the mini expander despite these
competitive cuts it would still cost
more than the ZX Spectrum once you've
added the expander and the RAM and it
didn't have the advantage of the huge
software library the sinclair machine
had on his side over in the US it was
the cheaper vic-20 and the TI 99
machines which buyers would opt for
instead in this price bracket it took
just six months for Mattel to throw in
the towel first dropping the Aquarius
and later the Intellivision two would
fall more than 600 employees were laid
off in the electronics division which
would then be shut down that wasn't the
end of the Aquarius story however Mattel
handed it back to manufacture a rather

the soon to be superseded device there

a little more than ambitious for a
machine that quickly gained the
reputation as one to avoid
